metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the purpose and benefits of installing a dense network of accelerometers in Japan after the 1995 Kobe earthquake. The network was used to record the maximum accelerations during the 2003 Kobe earthquake, which were located in a large area with accelerations exceeding 0.5 g. The analysis of the acceleration of ground movement in the Onagawa nuclear power plant helped determine the distribution of seismic activity in the area, despite the limited damage caused by the earthquake. The section also highlights the variability of seismic activity, as shown by the differences in acceleration values recorded at the MYG011 station (1.1 g in horizontal and 0.8 g in vertical) and on the site of the Onagawa nuclear power plant (0.225 g).

cartographie des accélérations maximales enregistré es pendant le séisme du 26 mai 2003 : cette carte f ait 
apparaître des accélérations supérieures à 0,5 g sur  une très grande zone, ponctuellement, l’accélérati on a atteint 
1g. 
30 mai 2003 L’analyse de l’accélération du mouvement du sol enr egistrée dans un rayon de 100 km autour du site nuc léaire 
d’Onagawa a permis de préciser la distribution spati ale du mouvement sismique (figure 6). Les valeurs 
d’accélération observées sont remarquablement élevé es au regard des distances des observations à la sou rce et du 
peu de dégâts engendrés. 
La très grande variabilité du mouvement sismique est  illustrée par les valeurs d’accélération enregistr ées à la 
station MYG011 (1,1 g en horizontal, 0,8 g en verti cal) et sur le site nucléaire (0,225 g ; source exp loitant de la

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the factors that contribute to the amplification of earthquake accelerations at the Ona gawa nuclear power plant in Japan. The section also examines the impact of the proximity of the MYG011 seismic station to the limite de plaques Eurasie-Pacifique on the amplification of earthquake accelerations in the area. The section also discusses the potential risks and challenges associated with building nuclear power plants on sedimentary rocks that are susceptible to amplifying earthquake accelerations, such as the MYG011 station in Japan. The section concludes that the 2003 earthquake in Japan was a complex event that required complementary studies to understand its effects on the surface, and that France, being an intraplaque sismotectonic region, is unlikely to experience a subduction earthquake of the same magnitude as the 2003 earthquake in Japan. The section also mentions other strong earthquakes in France in the past, such as the Faille de la Durance, Fa ille de Nîmes, and Alsace, which had a magnitude of 6.5 to 7.

Conclusions 
•Le séisme du 26 mai 2003, s’est produit dans une zo ne où l’activité sismique est forte, mais pas la plus  
forte du Japon. Au cours de ce séisme, une faille i mportante de l’ordre de plusieurs dizaines de 
kilomètres a dû être activée en profondeur, à proximi té de la limite de plaques Eurasie-Pacifique. Les 
effets en surface de ce séisme (mouvements forts et  très variables, faibles dégâts) sont le reflet d’u n 
événement complexe dont la compréhension nécessiter a des études complémentaires. 
•La France métropolitaine est un domaine sismotecton ique intraplaque et un tel séisme de subduction 
ne peut pas s’y produire. Les plus forts séismes fra nçais relatés depuis mille ans, associés à des faill es

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses a magnitude 7.8 earthquake that occurred in Mexico on January 21, 2003. The epicenter was located in the ocean about 100 kilometers southwest of the state of Colima and about 600 kilometers east-southeast of Mexico City. The earthquake caused significant damage in the state of Colima, with many buildings collapsing and people being left without electricity for several hours. The earthquake was also felt in Mexico City, but no major damage was reported there. The section also mentions the impact of the earthquake on Mexico's seismic risk and infrastructure.

__data__.text:
Rappel des faits 
•Un important séisme de magnitude Mw = 7,8 a eu lieu au Mexique le 21 janvier à
20h06 heure locale (22 janvier à 02H06 GMT) (Source : United States Geological 
Survey). L’épicentre est localisé en mer à environ 100  kilomètres au sud-sud-
ouest de l’état de Colima, et à environ 600 km à l’ou est-sud-ouest de la ville de 
Mexico. D’après les premières estimations, l’épicen tre se situe à une latitude de 
18,22 degrés nord et à une longitude de 104,6 degrés  ouest, l’hypocentre étant 
localisé à une profondeur d’environ 10 km, selon le S ervicio Sismologico Nacional 
de l’Universidad Autonoma de Mexico (UNAM). 
• Selon l’Heraldo, un journal mexicain, c’est dans l ’état de Colima que se concentre 
la majorité des dégâts sans que leur évaluation soit  encore connue. Toutefois, de 
nombreuses habitations dans la capitale de l’état d e Colima ont subi de sévères 
dégâts. Les habitants ont été privés d’électricité pe ndant environ 6 heures. Le 
séisme a été ressenti dans la ville de Mexico, pourt ant très distante de la zone 
épicentrale, ce qui a donné lieu à des scènes de pani que, mais il n’y a pas de dégâts 
rapportés dans la ville. Mexico est en partie const ruite sur un lac asséché, qui a la 
particularité d’amplifier fortement les ondes sismiq ues (effet de site). Les 
destructions importantes survenues dans la ville de  Mexico lors du séisme du 19 
septembre 1985 (magnitude 8,1, distance 400 km) son t dues à ce phénomène. Séisme au Mexique

Le contexte tectonique 
Le Mexique est situé sur une zone de subduction entr e la plaque Cocos et la plaque Nord Américaine (Fig ures 1 et 
2). La plaque Cocos s’enfonce sous la plaque Nord A méricaine à une vitesse moyenne de 5 centimètres par  an. Le 
séisme qui s’est produit le 21 janvier 2003 résulte  du relâchement brutal des contraintes accumulées d u fait du 
rapprochement continu de ces deux plaques. 
22 janvier 2003 Figure 2 : Subduction de la plaque Cocos sous la pl aque Nord-américaine

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the Laguna Verde nuclear power plant in Mexico, which is the only nuclear power plant in the country. It is located 70 km northwest of Veracruz on the east coast and is approximately 90 km from the epicenter of the 2003 earthquake. The impact of the earthquake on the plant was minimal due to its strong distance from the epicenter. The plant consists of two boiling water reactors with a capacity of 650 MWe each.

3
Les installations nucléaires 
Le Mexique ne dispose que d’une unique centrale nuc léaire : Laguna Verde (2 réacteurs à eau bouillante de  650 
MWe chacun) située à 70 km au Nord-Ouest de Veracruz (côte est). Cette installation se situe à environ 90 0 
kilomètres de l’épicentre du séisme du 21 janvier 2 003. Compte tenu de son fort éloignement, l’amplitu de du 
mouvement sismique ressenti au niveau de la central e a sans doute été très faible, et sans conséquence pour les 
structures. 
22 janvier 2003

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the May 21, 2003 Algérie Earthquake, which had a magnitude of 6.7 and occurred at 19h45 local time (21 mai à 18h45 GMT) in Algeria. The epicenter was located in a coastal area approximately 80 kilometers east of the capital, with an estimated latitude of 36.89 degrees north and a longitude of 3.78 degrees east, and an hypocenter at a depth of approximately 10 kilometers. The earthquake caused significant damages and casualties in several localities east of Alger, including Rouïba and Boumerdès, and was felt as far away as Majorca, 300 kilometers from the epicenter. The Bureau d'évaluation des risques sismiques pour la sûreté des installations (BERSSIN) of the IRSN conducted research and expertises on the seismic risk in Algeria as a potential threat to nuclear power plants. The section also discusses the tectonic context of Algeria, which is located on the boundary between the African and Eurasian plates.

__data__.text:

•Jeudi 21 mai, un important séisme de magnitude 6,7 a eu lieu en Algérie à 19h45

• L’épicentre est localisé dans une zone côtière à env iron 80 kilomètres à l’est de la 
capitale, Alger. D’après les premières estimations,  l’épicentre se situe à une 
latitude de 36,89 degrés nord et à une longitude de 3,78 degrés est, l’hypocentre 
étant localisé àune profondeur d’environ 10 km. 
• Selon différentes sources d’information, d’importa nts dégâts et de nombreuses 
victimes sont à déplorer dans de nombreuses localité s à l’est d’Alger (notamment 
Rouïba et Boumerdès). Le séisme a été ressenti à gran de distance de l’épicentre 
(Majorque à environ 300 km). Il a été enregistré sur l ’ensemble des réseaux 
sismologiques mondiaux. Séisme en Algérie

metadata.document_title: "Assessing the Impact and Damages of the May 21, 2003 Algérie Earthquake: Tectonic Context and Earthquake Risk in Algeria: Understanding the Seismic Threat to Nuclear Power Plants"

metadata.prev_section_summary: The section discusses the May 21, 2003 Algérie Earthquake, which had a magnitude of 6.7 and occurred at 19h45 local time (21 mai à 18h45 GMT) in Algeria. The epicenter was located in a coastal area approximately 80 kilometers east of the capital, with an estimated latitude of 36.89 degrees north and a longitude of 3.78 degrees east, and an hypocenter at a depth of approximately 10 kilometers. The earthquake caused significant damages and casualties in several localities east of Alger, including Rouïba and Boumerdès, and was felt as far away as Majorca, 300 kilometers from the epicenter. The Bureau d'évaluation des risques sismiques pour la sûreté des installations (BERSSIN) of the IRSN conducted research and expertises on the seismic risk in Algeria as a potential threat to nuclear power plants. The section also discusses the tectonic context of Algeria, which is located on the boundary between the African and Eurasian plates.
metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the tectonic context of Algeria and its impact on the seismic threat to nuclear power plants in the country. It explains that Algeria is located on a tectonic plate boundary between Africa and Eurasia, where the plates converge at a rate of 6 millimeters per year. This convergence generates significant stress, which can cause certain faults to be activated and produce seismic waves that propagate to the surface. The section identifies the Atlas mountain chain as the location of the principal active faults in Algeria, and notes that the movement of the faults is consistent with the global movement of tectonic plates. The section also mentions the May 21, 2003 earthquake in Algeria and suggests that the prolongation of a major local fault (the faille de Thenia) may have been activated during that event.

__data__.text:
de l’IRSN

à risque 
1FS 6 
22 mai 2003 
22 mai 2003 www.irsn.org CONTACT : 
IRSN/BERSSIN Le contexte tectonique 
L’Algérie se situe sur une frontière active de plaq ues au niveau de la convergence de 
l’Afrique et de l’Eurasie(figure 1). Ces plaques se  rapprochent à une vitesse de 
l’ordre de 6 millimètres par an, ce qui génère une accumulation importante de 
contraintes. Lorsque ces contraintes deviennent tro p fortes, certaines failles 
peuvent être mises en mouvement. Le déplacement rap ide des bords de la faille 
génère alors des ondes sismiques qui se propagent j usqu'à la surface. Les principales 
failles actives sont localisées au niveau de la cha îne de montagne nord-africaine 
(Atlas). Le mouvement relatif des bords de la faill e tel qu’il a été enregistré par les 
sismomètres montre un raccourcissement cohérent ave c le mouvement global des 
plaques. Pour le moment, la faille qui est à l’origi ne du séisme du 21 mai 2003 n’est 
pas identifiée. Compte tenu des premières informati ons sismologiques, la 
prolongation orientale de la faille majeure connue localement (faille de Thenia) 
pourrait avoir été activée lors de ce séisme.

metadata.section_summary:
The section discusses the historical significance of earthquakes in Algeria, with a focus on the 2003 earthquake. The country is located in a region of seismic convergence, and has experienced several destructive earthquakes throughout its history, including the 1715 earthquake in Alger, which resulted in 20,000 deaths, and the 1980 earthquake in El Asnam, which resulted in 2600 deaths. However, the 2003 earthquake was the first major earthquake in the region of its epicenter. The section also discusses the impact of the 2003 earthquake on the built environment and human life in Algeria, and the country's response to the disaster. The section also discusses the current preparedness measures in place to mitigate the effects of future earthquakes in Algeria, and their effectiveness in reducing the impact of such disasters.

Key Topics:

* Historical significance of earthquakes in Algeria
* The 2003 earthquake in Algeria
* Impact of the 2003 earthquake on the built environment and human life in Algeria
* Preparedness measures to mitigate the effects of future earthquakes in Algeria

__data__.text:
I  N  F  O  R  M  A  T  I  O  N 
2
L’histoire sismique de l’Algérie 
Compte tenu de sa localisation dans une zone de con vergence de plaques, l’Algérie est une région à fort e sismicité
(figure 2). Au cours de son histoire, elle a subi p lusieurs séismes destructeurs. Parmi les plus notab les, on peut 
citer : 1715, séisme d’Alger, 20000 morts ; 1954 sé isme d’Orléansville (EL Asnam), magnitude 6,7, 1 200  morts, 20 
000 bâtiments détruits ; 1980 séisme d’El Asnam, ma gnitude 7,1, 2600 morts. 
Néanmoins, aucun séisme majeur n’avait été répertori é jusqu'alors dans la région de l’épicentre. La figu re 3 
montre que l’intensité maximale observée (évaluation  des dégâts dus aux séismes) y est faible au regard  d’autres 
régions de l’Algérie. En effet, dans cette région l ’intensité maximale observée ne dépasse pas V (voir légende de 
la figure 3). Compte tenu de l’importance des destr uctions engendrées par le séisme du 21 mai 2003, l’ intensité
de cette secousse est a priori supérieure à VIII. Un e évaluation précise ne pourra être réalisée qu’apr ès enquête 
sur le terrain. 
22 mai 2003

L’Algérie ne dispose que de réacteurs nucléaires de  recherche de faible puissance. Les centrales nuclé aires les 
plus proches se situent en Espagne (Vandellosà530 k m de l'épicentre). Compte tenu de la distance impor tante des 
centrales, aucun effet notable n’est attendu àla su ite du séisme du 21 mai 2003.

•Le séisme du 21 mai 2003, très important, s’est pro duit dans une zone où l’activité sismique était 
considérée comme modérée par rapport à la sismicité d ’autres régions de l’Algérie. Au cours de ce

__data__.text:
s retient ce type d’événement. 
Les effets de site probables 
Les localités de Rouïba et Boumerdès dans lesquelles  d’importants dégâts ont été relevés se situent sur des 
terrains meubles (formations récentes peu compactée s). Ce type de formation géologique peut être à l’or igine 
d’amplifications du mouvement du sol lors d’un séis me (effets de site) et par conséquent, en l’état ac tuel des 
informations disponibles, pourrait contribuer àexpl iquer l’importance des dégâts dans ces localités. 
Ce type d’effets, déjà identifiés lors de séismes ré cents (Kobé par exemple), est étudié par l’IRSN. Les études 
menées notamment en Californie, à Grenoble et dans l e Golfe de Corinthe (Grèce) consistent à instrumente r un 
site en profondeur et en surface de manière à compar er les réponses des différentes couches du sol sous  
sollicitations sismiques. (voir la fiche sur les re cherches menées par l’IRSN dans le domaine sismique ) 
La dernière version de la règle fondamentale de sûr eté relative à la prise en compte du risque sismique pour la 
sûreté des installations nucléaires comprend des exi gences spécifiques concernant les effets de site.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the Lourdes Earthquake of November 17, 2006. The Laboratory of Detection Geophysical (LDG) of the CEA estimates the magnitude of the earthquake to be 5.2+/-0.39 on the Richter scale, with an epicenter located at a latitude of 42.97° Nord and a longitude of 0.1° Ouest. The Bureau d'évaluation des risques sismiques pour la sûreté des installations (BERSSIN) of the IRSN estimates the depth of the earthquake to be between 5 and 10 km. The section also mentions that the earthquake was reported by various news organizations, including AFP, Radio France, and Nouvel Observateur. The location of the epicenter of the earthquake is also provided, as well as the contact information for Catherine Berge at IRSN/BERSSIN.

Rappel des faits
Vendredi 17 novembre 2006, à 18h19 temps universel, un séisme 
de magnitude modérée s’est produit à environ 10 km au SSW 
de Lourdes (65).
Le Laboratoire de détection géophysiqu e (LDG) du CEA estime la magnitude 
du séisme à 5.2+/-0.39 sur l’échelle de Richter, avec un épicentre situé
à une latitude de 42,97° Nord et à une longitude de 0,1° Ouest (cf. figure). Le choc principal a été suivi par quelques répliques (dont une à 3.3
le 19 novembre).
Des évaluations faites par d’autres organismes conduisent à des magnitudes de l’ordre de 4.5 .
La profondeur du séisme est estimée entre 5 et 10 km .
L’événement sismique a été relayé par divers  organes de presse (AFP, Radio France, 
Nouvel Observateur…).

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses a 2006 earthquake that occurred in the Argelès-Gazost region of France and its impact on the region's infrastructure and nuclear power plants. The earthquake was felt strongly in the Hautes-Pyrénées department, with some damage reported in Lourdes and brief power outages in some Hautes-Pyrénées communities. The earthquake was located in the Faille nord-pyrénéenne region, which is known for its moderate and frequent seismic activity. The analysis of historical earthquakes in the region reveals that it has experienced more significant earthquakes in the past, with some causing significant damage to buildings and having a magnitude of up to 6.5. The recent earthquake on November 17, 2006, is considered significant, as it is one of the most important in magnitude locally in the past 40 years. The section also discusses the impact of the earthquake on the region's infrastructure and nuclear power plants, but no specific details are provided on the measures taken to mitigate the impact of future earthquakes on these facilities.

__data__.text:
Ce séisme a été fortement ressenti dans le département des Hautes-Pyrénées,
principalement dans le pays de Lourdes, mais aussi plus modérément dans les départements voisins 
des Pyrénées-Atlantiques et de Haute-Garonne. De légers dégâts ont été signalés dans les environs 
de Lourdes (chutes de cheminées), tandis que de brèves coupures d’électricité ont aus si affecté
des communes des Hautes-Pyrénées.Témoignages recueillis
Bureau Central Sismologique Français (www.bcsf.prd.fr)
Le séisme du 17/11/2006 est localisé dans la  région de la Faille nord-pyrénéenne,
autour de laquelle se concentre la si smicité modérée et fréquente de la région. Cette région est la plus active 
de la France métropolita ine. Les premiers travaux sur le séisme du 17/11/2006 montrent que le mouvement est 
extensif sur une faille de direction E-W. Les résultat s confortent la connaissance actuelle des mécanismes à
l’origine de la sismicité régionale.
L’analyse des séismes historiques révèle que la région a déjà subi des séismes plus significatifs.
Ceux-ci ont occasionné des dégâts importants sur le  bâti (intensité épicentrale supérieure à VII MSK).
Le plus fort de ces séismes historiques (21/6/1660) aurait eu une magnitude proche de 6.5.
Sur la période récente pour laquelle des enregistrements sont disponibles, le séisme du 17/11/2006 apparaît 
toutefois d’importance significative. Ainsi, parmi les séismes enregistrés depuis plus de 40 ans dans un rayon de 
30 km, celui du 17/11/2006 apparaît comme le deuxième le plus important en magnitude locale.

The earthquake was felt strongly in the Hautes-Pyrénées department, with some damage reported in Lourdes and brief power outages in some Hautes-Pyrénées communities. The earthquake was located in the Faille nord-pyrénéenne region, which is known for its moderate and frequent seismic activity. The analysis of historical earthquakes in the region reveals that it has experienced more significant earthquakes in the past, with some causing significant damage to buildings and having a magnitude of up to 6.5. The recent earthquake on November 17, 2006, is considered significant, as it is one of the most important in magnitude locally in the past 40 years. The section also discusses the impact of the earthquake on the region's infrastructure and nuclear power plants, but no specific details are provided on the measures taken to mitigate the impact of future earthquakes on these facilities.
metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the analysis of seismic activity in the Hautes-Pyrénées region and its impact on nuclear power plants and historical and recent earthquakes in the Argelès-Gazost region. The most significant earthquake in the Argelès-Gazost region in the past 40 years was the one that occurred on November 17, 2006, which had a magnitude of 5.5. The distance of the Golfech nuclear power plant from the epicenter of this earthquake was 145 km, and it was not affected. The intensity of the earthquake that occurred on June 21, 1660, in the CEA region was VIII-IX on the Mercalli scale, which is equivalent to a magnitude of 6.5. The section also discusses the impact of the earthquake on the nuclear power plant and the inspection of the barrages hydro-électriques by EDF. The context sismotectonique of the region is also provided, including the three most significant historical earthquakes in the region, their dates, longitudes, latitudes, magnitudes, and distances from the epicenter.

plus fort de ces séismes historiques (21/6/1660) aurait eu une magnitude proche de 6.5.
Sur la période récente pour laquelle des enregistrements sont disponibles, le séisme du 17/11/2006 apparaît 
toutefois d’importance significative. Ainsi, parmi les séismes enregistrés depuis plus de 40 ans dans un rayon de 
30 km, celui du 17/11/2006 apparaît comme le deuxième le plus important en magnitude locale.
Impact sur les installations nucléaires
La région concernée n’accueille aucune installation nucléaire.
Le site le plus proche, l’installation nucléaire EDF de  Golfech est située à 145 km. La secousse n’y a pas été
ressentie. 
Les caractéristiques du séisme soulignent qu’il est associé aux failles pyrénéen nes et qu’il n’est pas 
représentatif de la zone de faible activité sismotectoni que (Bassin aquitain) où est localisée l’installation de 
Golfech. 
Selon l’Agence France Presse (19/11/2006), l’inspection par EDF de ses barrages hydro-électriques 
a permis de vérifier l’absence d’impact du séisme sur les ouvrages les plus proches de l’épicentre. Contexte sismotectonique

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the exploitation of accelerometric data for earthquake attenuation estimation and nuclear safety evaluation. The earthquake that occurred on November 17, 2006, in the Pyrénées is significant in the context of France's nuclear safety, although it was relatively small compared to historical regional earthquakes. The attenuation of seismic waves in the Pyrénées was estimated using data collected from this earthquake. The density of seismic stations in the region of the earthquake's epicenter is related to the estimation of seismic wave attenuation. The section also mentions the Réseau AccélérométriquePermanent (RAP) and the application of the Règle Fondamentale de Sûreté (RFS) for the evaluation of nuclear safety.

metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:

metadata.prev_section_summary: The section discusses the exploitation of accelerometric data for earthquake attenuation estimation and nuclear safety evaluation. The earthquake that occurred on November 17, 2006, in the Pyrénées is significant in the context of France's nuclear safety, although it was relatively small compared to historical regional earthquakes. The attenuation of seismic waves in the Pyrénées was estimated using data collected from this earthquake. The density of seismic stations in the region of the earthquake's epicenter is related to the estimation of seismic wave attenuation. The section also mentions the Réseau AccélérométriquePermanent (RAP) and the application of the Règle Fondamentale de Sûreté (RFS) for the evaluation of nuclear safety.
metadata.section_summary:
* The purpose of using accelerometric data for earthquake attenuation estimation and nuclear safety evaluation is to compare the estimated seismic wave distances and magnitudes with predicted values using the law of attenuation of seismic waves.
* The law of attenuation of seismic waves is used in the evaluation of safety in nuclear sites, specifically in the application of the Règle Fondamentale de Sûreté 2001-01.
* Magnitude local (Ml) and magnitude of moment (Mw) are two types of seismic magnitudes used in seismic wave analysis. Ml is determined by the CEA from enregistrements of their network, while Mw is a more precise and representative measure of the energy produced by the event.
* The IRSN obtained a value of Mw=4.4 for the given earthquake, which is comparable to values obtained from other organisms.
* The section discusses the use of accelerometric data for earthquake attenuation estimation and nuclear safety evaluation, specifically in the context of the law of attenuation of seismic waves and the Règle Fondamentale de Sûreté 2001-01. It also explains the difference between Ml and Mw and how they are used in seismic wave analysis.

figure).
Le calcul de magnitude.
La magnitude locale (Ml), déterminée 
par le CEA à partir des enregistrements de son réseau, est une valeur issue d’un calcul semi-automatique qui répond aux objectifs de ce réseau d’alerte. Pour ce séisme, le nombre important 
de signaux disponibles a permis le calcul d’un 
autre type de magnitude, la magnitude de moment (Mw), plus précise qu’une Ml et plus représentative de l’énergie produite par l’événement. 
L’IRSN obtient une valeur de Mw=4.4 
comparable à celles venant d’autres organismes.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the earthquake that occurred at the Chinon Nuclear Power Plant on November 5, 2006. The earthquake was estimated to have a magnitude of 4.1+/-0.38 on the Richter scale, with an epicenter located at a latitude of 47.30 North and a longitude of 0.08 East. The section also mentions the difficulty in evaluating the depth of the earthquake with precision due to the distance between the epicenter and the nearest sismologic station. The event was relayed by various media outlets, including the RMC-Info and the association "Sortir du Nucléaire". The Bureau d'évaluation des risques sismiques pour la sûreté des installations (BERSSIN) of the IRSN conducted research and expertises on the alea sismique as a source of external aggression to the installations at risk.

__data__.text:
Localisation
de l’épicentre du séisme
(source: CEA/LDG)Rappel des faits
Dimanche 5 novembre 2006, à 00h37 temps universel, un séisme de faible magnitude s’est produit à une dizaine de kilomètres de la centrale nucléaire de Chinon.
Le Laboratoire de détection géophysiqu e (LDG) du CEA estime la magnitude 
du séisme à 4.1+/-0.38 sur l’échelle de Richter avec un épicentre situé à une 
latitude de 47.30 Nord et à une longitude de 0.08 Est (cf. figure). La profondeur du séisme est plus difficile à évaluer avec  précision, la station sismologique 
la plus proche étant située à 73 km de l’épicentre.
L’événement sismique a été relayé par divers  organes de presse dont la station RMC-
Info qui a également diffusé une déclaration du porte-parole de l’association « Sortir 
du Nucléaire » mettant en doute la sûreté de l’installation.Séisme de Chinon

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the 2006 earthquake in the departments of Maine et Loire and Indre et Loire, which was felt in the cities of Longue-jumelles, Saumur, Avoine, Beaumont-en-Véron, Savigny-en-Véron, and Bourgueuil. The earthquake caused no reported damage, but the Bureau Central Sismologique Français (BCSF) collected information from the population to determine the zone of perception, intensity, and risk sismique local. The earthquake was felt in the region of the Centre opérationnel départemental d'incendie et de secours (Codis) in the departments of Maine et Loire and Indre et Loire. The earthquake occurred in the southwest of the Paris basin, where the sédiments cover the eastern part of the massif armoricain. The earthquake was felt in the direction of NW-SE and NNW-SSW.

__data__.text:
Suivant les témoignages (le 05.11.06 à 2h30), ce séisme a été ressenti dans les deux 
départements du Maine et Loire (4 9) et de l’Indre et Loire (37).
A la connaissance de l’IRSN, aucun dégât n’a été signalé . Le Bureau Central Sismologique Français (BCSF) 
a reçu 2 témoignages dans les villes de Longue-j umelles et Saumur où le séisme a été perçu comme 
un grondement sourd et lointain. Le Codis (Centre opér ationnel départemental d'incendie et de secours) 
du département du Maine et Loire a reçu 3 appels dans la région de Saumur. Le Codis du département 
de l’Indre et Loire, a reçu quelques appels signalant des effets vibratoires sur les communes d’Avoine (37), 
Beaumont-en-Véron (37), Savigny-en-Véron (37) et Bourgueuil (37). 
Une déflagration aurait été entendue à Beaumont-en-Véron. Le BCSF procède à une collecte d’informations par 
Internet auprès de la population, afin de préciser la zone de perception de l’événement, d’évaluer l’intensité
de la secousse et ainsi de mieux co nnaître le risque sismique local.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the 5 November 2006 earthquake that affected the regions of Maine-et-Loire and Indre-et-Loire in France. The epicenter of the earthquake was located near the CNPE site in Chinon. The region was affected by the "armoricaines" faults, which produce moderate, frequent, and diffuse seismic activity. The analysis of historical earthquakes shows that the region has experienced more significant earthquakes in the past, such as the Loudun 1711 earthquake, which had a magnitude of 5.5 to 6. The context of the sismotectonic activity in the region is discussed, including the principal earthquakes recorded within a 50 km radius of Chinon and the attention paid to the 5 November 2006 earthquake due to its proximity to the CNPE site.

__data__.text:
en ligne sur le site: http://www.bcsf.prd.frTémoignages recueillis autour de l’épicentre
d’après le Com muniqué du Bureau central sismologique français (BCSF)
La région af fectée par le séisme du 5 novembre 2006 est située à l’extrémité sud-ouest du bassin 
de Paris  dont les sédiments recouvrent la partie orientale du massif armoricain. Les failles « armoricaines » de 
direction NW-SE et NNW-SSW y produisent une sismicité modérée, relativement fréquente et diffuse.
L’analyse des séismes historiques montre que la région a déjà subi des séismes plus significatifs
qui ont occasionné des dégâts sur le bâti à moins de 40 km du site de Chinon (intensité épicentrale supérieure à
VI MSK). Le plus fort de ces séismes historiques (Loudun 1711) a une magnitude estimée entre 5,5 et 6.Contexte sismotectonique

enregistrée dans la région . Ainsi, huit séismes de magnitude voisine ont été enregistrés par le réseau 
national depuis 1962. L’attention portée à cet événement tient à sa localisation à proximité

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the significance of the distance between the center of a nuclear power plant and the epicenter of an earthquake in terms of the safety of nuclear power plants. It also explains how the magnitude of an earthquake affects the estimation of the seismic risk on the site of a nuclear power plant. The specific instruments required to detect and control the movement of a nuclear power plant in the event of a significant earthquake are also discussed, along with the role of rule I.3.b in ensuring the safety of the installations. The section mentions the Chinon nuclear power plant, which is the oldest site of EDF and has three reactors in shutdown and four units of production in operation. The section also explains the use of detectors and accelerometers to detect and control the movement of the nuclear power plant in the event of a significant earthquake, and how the rule I.3.b of 08/06/1984 outlines the specific dispositifs that must be adopted by nuclear power plants to ensure their safety.

__data__.text:
Les enseignements
La faible distance entre le centre nucléaire d’ EDF et l’épicentre du séisme du 5 novembre 2006 
conforte le choix d’un scénario de séisme sous le site.
La faible magnitude de l’événement ne remet pas en cause l’estimation de l’aléa  sismique sur le site 
de Chinon.
10 novembre 2006Le séisme s’est produit à proxi mité de Chinon qui est le plus  ancien site nucléaire d'EDF.
Il accueille 3 tranches à l’arrêt et en cours de déconstr uction et 4 unités de production de 900 MW construites 
dans les années 1980 et actuellement en exploitation.
De façon à assurer la sûreté des installations en cas de séisme significatif, les centrales 
nucléaires doivent être équipées d’une inst rumentation spécifique pour la détection 
des mouvements sismiques. Les enregistrements sismiques permettent également d’effectuer 
un contrôle a posteriori du co mportement des structures en regard du niveau de vibrations auxquel les elles ont 
été soumises. L’ensemble des disposit ifs qui doivent être adoptés par les centrales nucléaires pour assurer la 
sécurité des installations est décrit par la règle I.3.b du 08/06/1984. 
Les détecteurs déclenchent le système d’enregistrement dès l’instant où le seuil de 0.01g est at teint 
ou dépassé à l’intérieur du bâtiment. Quatre accéléromètr es sont asservis à ce système de détection, dont un 
à l’extérieur des bâtiments.
D’après les informations recuei llies par l’IRSN auprès d’EDF (communication orale entre chargé
d’affaire du site Chinon IRSN et un correspondant EDF sur le site de Chinon), le séisme n’a pas déclenché
les accéléromètres

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the sismic detection system of a nuclear power plant in Chinon, France. The threshold value for the accelerometer readings in the sismic detection system is 0.01g, and there are four accelerometers used in the system, including one located outside the buildings. Two scenarios retained by EDF for characterizing the seismic risk of the Chinon nuclear power plant are discussed, with corresponding magnitudes and distances involved in each scenario. The magnitude of the closest seismic event to the site retained by EDF is estimated to be significantly larger than the magnitude of the event felt on November 5, 2006.

D’après les informations recuei llies par l’IRSN auprès d’EDF (communication orale entre chargé

les accéléromètres du système de détection sismique de la centrale. La station du réseau 
accélérométrique national (RAP) la plus proche du CN PE est située à plus de 70 km : on ne dispose donc, pour
ce séisme, d’aucun enregistrement du mouvement du sol à proximité du site.Les installations nucléaires à proximité
L’événement par rapport au niveau d’aléa retenu dans les 
évaluations de sûreté
Selon la réglementation en vigueur actuellement (RFS 2001-01), EDF retient deux scénarii pour 
caractériser l’aléa sismique du site de Chinon. Ils correspondent à l’occurrence d’un séisme à courte et 
grande distance du site. Ces scénarii sont associés à d es couples magnitude-distance de M=5,5 à 9 km sous 
l’installation et M=6,3 à 30 km du site.
La magnitude du séisme proche du site retenu par EDF est ainsi d’environ un ordre de grandeur supérieure 
à la magnitude de l’évènement ressenti le 5 novembre 2006. L’énergie sismique libérée par un séisme de 
magnitude 5.5, tel que celui retenu par EDF, est environ 200 fois plus forte que celle libérée par le séisme

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the 2007 Martinique earthquake, which occurred on November 29, 2007, at 19h00 TU (15h00 local time) in the Antilles French. The earthquake had a magnitude of 7.4 and its epicenter was located at a latitude of 14,951° North and a longitude of 61,24° West. The earthquake was felt by the population of Martinique for at least 50 seconds and even in neighboring countries such as Colombia, Venezuela, and Guyana. The earthquake was caused by the subduction of the North American Plate under the Caribbean Plate, despite its magnitude, it caused limited damage due to its depth of over 140 km. The Bureau d'évaluation des risques sismiques pour la sûreté des installations (BERSSIN) of the IRSN conducted research and expertises on the risk of seismic activity on nuclear power plants.

__data__.text:
Rappel des faits
Jeudi 29 novembre 2007, à 19h00 TU (15h00 heure locale), un séisme de 
magnitude importante s’est produit à environ 40 km au nord/nord-ouest de la 
préfecture de la Martinique, Fort-de- France, dans les Antilles françaises.
La magnitude de moment (Mw) est estimée à 7,4. L’épicentre est situé à une 
latitude de 14,951° Nord et à une longitude de 61,24° Ouest (Figure 1). Le séisme 
s’est produit à environ 143 km de profondeur. (source : USGS NEIC)
L’événement sismique a été très largement ressenti par la population martiniquaise pendant au moins 50 secondes voire plus ieurs minutes. La secousse a même été
ressentie en Colombie, au Venezuela et en Guyane. Une dizaine de répliques non 
ressenties ont été enregistrées selon l’Obse rvatoire volcanologique et sismologique 
de Guadeloupe (OVSG).
Ce séisme relié à la subduction(1)de la plaque Nord Américaine sous la plaque 
Caraïbes, bien que de magnitude importante, s’est initié à plus de 140 km de profondeur, ce qui explique les dégâts maté riels et humains relativement limités.  
Cette grande profondeur a aussi rapidement écarté le risque de tsunami destructeur 
(d’après le centre d'alerte au tsunami dans le Pacifique à Hawaï).Séisme de Martinique

__data__.text:
I  N  F  O  R  M  A  T  I  O  N
12 décembre 2007 2
(2)Mouvement relatif de deux plaque s tectoniques qui se rapprochent.Contexte sismotectonique
La Martinique et la Guadeloupe appartiennent aux peti tes Antilles. Les petites Antilles sont constituées d’un 
chapelet d’îles volcaniques long de 1000 km des Iles Vierges à Trinidad et Tobago. Ces îles sont nées de la 
subduction du plancher océanique atlantique (appartenant à la plaque nord-américaine) sous la plaque caraïbe. La 
vitesse de convergence(2)entre les deux plaques est de l’ordre de 2 cm/an selon une direction ENE-WSW : des 
déplacements génèrent des déformations, une sismicité et des phénomènes volcaniques importants dans les petites Antilles. La sismicité se manifeste à travers des séismes superficiels et profonds liés à la subduction ainsi 
que par des séismes mineurs liés au volcanisme. 
Cette zone active est caractérisée par une sismicité histo rique et instrumentale notable. Les séismes historiques 
majeurs qui ont affecté les îles sont répertoriés dans le tableau 1, et localisés sur la figure 2. L’un des séismes historiques les plus destructeurs est celui du 8 février 1843 qui a affecté la Guadeloupe. Ce séisme, dont la 
magnitude est estimée à 7,5 – 8 (source BRGM) a causé la mort de plus de 3000 personnes, particulièrement à
Pointe-à-Pitre. La figure 3 illustre la distribution de la  sismicité instrumentale (extraite du catalogue de l’USGS-
NEIC) enregistrée depuis près de 40 ans le long de l’Arc antillais.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses a violent earthquake that struck the eastern Caribbean on Thursday, with the epicenter located between Martinique and Dominique at approximately 150 km of depth. The earthquake affected Martinique, where three people were victims of cardiac malaises, with one of them dying and the other two being hospitalized. In addition, a hundred people were reported to have malaises on the island, and six people were injured or killed due to falling debris. The earthquake also caused damage in Barbados, where several buildings were destroyed in the capital Bridgetown, resulting in one light injury. No casualties were reported in Guadeloupe, but several people suffered from various injuries after jumping from windows in fear.

et Dominique à environ 150 km de profondeur. En Martinique, la plus touchée des îles, trois personnes ont étévictimes de malaises cardiaques : l'une d'elles est décédé et les deux autres ont été hospitalisées. Une centaine de malaises sur l'île et six blessés par défenestration dont  un grave ont également été recensés (d’après la Sécurité
Civile). Un blessé léger a été signalé à La Barbade, où pl usieurs immeubles ont été détruits dans la capitale 
Bridgetown. En Guadeloupe, aucune victime n’a été recensé e. Plusieurs personnes, prises de panique ou ayant 
sauté par les fenêtres souffrent de blessures diverses comme des entorses en Martinique où des milliers d’habitants affolés sont sortis dans les rues.

__data__.text:
12 décembre 2007 3I  N  F  O  R  M  A  T  I  O  N
Le Réseau Accéléromé trique Permanent français (RAP), qui fédère de nombreux organismes, dont l’IRSN, 
impliqués dans l’étude du risque sismique, dispose d’une trentaine de stations accélérométriques aux Antilles. Ces 
instruments enregistrent l’accélération du sol lors du séisme. Ces données sont très importantes pour les experts ; elles servent notamment à définir et faire évoluer les mo dèles de prédiction des mouvements de terrain et les 
normes de construction parasismiques.
Pour le séisme du 29 novembre 2007, les données accélérométriques ont été disponibles sur le site du RAP ( www-
rap.obs.ujf-grenoble.fr ) dès le lendemain. La figure 5 ci-après co mpare les valeurs de l’accélération maximales 
du terrain (appelée PGA) mesurée en plusieurs stations (voi r localisation en figure 4), aux valeurs prédites par une 
relation empirique, fondée sur les centaines de donnée s recueillies dans des zones de subduction (Youngs et al, 
1997).
La figure 5 illustre la grande variabil ité, d’environ un facteur 10, des données observées. Cette variabilité est le 
résultat de la complexité de la rupture de la faille et de la propagation des ondes sismiques dans un milieu de subduction. Elle est essentielle à prendre en compte pour l’estimation de l’aléa et pour la conception des normes 
de construction plus sures.En Martinique, de nombreux bâtiments ont subi des dégâts  importants, tels que l’effondrement d’une dalle sur une 
dizaine de véhicules à Fort-de-France, et d’un bâtiment abritant une banque au Lamentin. Des établissements 
publics de la Martinique - préfecture, écoles, collèges - o nt été

publics de la Martinique - préfecture, écoles, collèges - o nt été évacués, des bâtiments fissurés. La préfecture a 
indiqué que «toutes les routes nationales et les départem entales sont praticables», et précisé que «le port et 
l’aéroport fonctionnent norm alement». Les hôpitaux fonctionnent aussi normalement, à l’exception de l’hôpital 
de Trinité, où une tour de 8 étages «gravement fissu rée» a été évacuée. Le courant, coupé pour un tiers des 
habitants, a été rétabli presque partout dans la soirée. 
En Guadeloupe, plusieurs milliers de personnes ont été éga lement privées d’électricité. En revanche, aucun dégât 
n’était enregistré. 
Par décision du Ministère de l’intérieur, tous les établiss ements scolaires de la Guadeloupe et de Martinique ont 
été fermés jusqu’au lundi 3 décembre afin de permettre « un diagnostic de sécurité » des bâtiments. La même 
décision a été prise dans les collectivités d’outre-mer de Saint-Martin et de Saint-Barthélémy, situées à 250 km au 
nord de Pointe-à-Pitre.Impact sur les bâtiments et les réseaux

The first study, conducted in December 2022, aimed to provide a "diagnostic of security" for buildings. metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the high seismic activity in Martinique and Guadeloupe, which are in the zone of highest seismic risk in France. The Plan Séisme piloté by MEDAD, launched in 2004, includes strong actions towards the Antilles, with a priority and significant funding (over 300 M€) focused on strengthening the built environment. The earthquake of November 29, 2007, is characterized as a subduction-zone earthquake, which placed Martinique and Guadeloupe in the zone of highest seismic risk in France. The earthquake, located near Martinique, was strongly felt throughout the Arc Antillais and as far as Venezuela, Colombia, and Guyana. The final damage assessment, including both material and human losses, associated with this earthquake is not yet established. The section also highlights the role of panic reactions in the overall damage and loss of life associated with the November 29, 2007 earthquake in the Antilles and compares it to the impact of other natural disasters in the region.

__data__.text:
La Martinique et la Guadeloupe sont dans la zone de sismicité la plus élevée dans la réglementation actuelle 
française pour le bâtiment conventionnel, et le resteront dans le futur zonage sismique. Le Plan Séisme piloté par 
le MEDAD et lancé fin 2004 comporte des actions très fortes vers les Antilles, avec une priorité et des 
financements (plus de 300 M€) orientés vers le renforcement du bâti. La première phase du Plan vise les 
établissements scolaires et sociaux ainsi que les centres de crise, une seconde phase, qui devrait débuter en 2012 être consacrée à la rénovation de deux centres hospital iers. (source Actu-Environnement, article de Janvier 2007).Prise en compte du risq ue sismique aux Antilles
Les enseignements
Le séisme du 29 novembre 2007 est caractéristiqu e des évènements sismiques de subduction, qui 
placent la Martinique et la Guad eloupe dans la zone d’aléa sism ique la plus forte en France.
Le séisme, localisé à proximité de la Martinique, a ét é très fortement ressenti dans tout l’Arc Antillais 
et jusqu’au Venezuela, Colombie et Guyane. Le bi lan définitif des dégâts matériels et humains (en 
termes de blessés voire de décès) associé à ce séisme n’est pas établi.
La grande profondeur du séisme a rapidement exclu l’occurrence d’un tsunami et limité les dommages. 
Les victimes sont dues davantage à des réaction s de panique plus qu’à des dommages sur le bâti.
L’exploitation des données accélérométrique illustre la grande variabilité des données de mouvements 
de terrain observées dans cette zone.Figure 4 Figure 5I  N  F  O  R  M  A  T  I  O

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses an earthquake that occurred in Niigata, Japan in July 2007. The earthquake had a magnitude of 6.6 and its epicenter was located near the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear power plant. The earthquake occurred in the sea and was caused by a fault system that was not previously known to be active. The earthquake caused damage to the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear power plant, resulting in 67 anomalies. An expert mission was conducted by the AIEA at the request of the Japanese government to assess the damage caused by the earthquake.

__data__.text:
Rappel des faits
Lundi 16 juillet, à 1h13 (10h13 heure locale), un séisme de magnitude 
importante s’est produit dans la préfecture de Niigata dans l’île principale de 
Honshu .
La magnitude de moment (Mw) est estimée à 6,6 (sources : NEID, JMA, Harvard CMT, 
USGS NEIC). L’épicentre est situé à une lati tude de 37,5° Nord et à une longitude de 
138,6° Est (Figure 1), soit à une distance d’environ 10 km de la centrale nucléaire 
de Kashiwazaki-Kariwa. Le choc principal a été suivi par de nombreuses répliques 
dont une de magnitude égale à 5,6 qui s’ est produite environ 5 heures après la 
première secousse.
Le séisme s’est produit en mer à une prof ondeur estimée entre 10 et 15 km sur un 
système de failles qui n’était pas claireme nt identifié comme étant actif avant ce 
séisme.
L’événement sismique a été relayé par dive rs organes de presse, mentionnant en 
particulier les conséquences sur la centrale  nucléaire de Kashiwazaki-Kariwa (voir la 
note d'information du 20 juillet 2007 faisant état de 67 anomalies).
Une mission d’experts a été conduite par l’AIEA à la demande du gouvernement 
japonais du 6 au 10 août 2007 ( voir le rapport de la mission sur le site 
www.iaea.org ).Séisme de Chu-Etsu-Oki (Japon)

metadata.section_summary:
The section discusses Japan's geological location in relation to tectonic plate convergence and the types of seismic activity that occur in Japan due to this location. It highlights the significance of the Chu-Etsu-Oki earthquake in relation to Japan's tectonic convergence and nuclear power plants. The section also mentions the importance of reconnaissance geophysical studies to better understand the geometrical structure of the faults activated during the earthquake and to examine the possibility of a new active fault emerging on the site of the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear power plant.

Key topics:

* Japan's geological location in relation to tectonic plate convergence
* Types of seismic activity in Japan due to tectonic plate convergence
* Significance of the Chu-Etsu-Oki earthquake in relation to Japan's tectonic convergence and nuclear power plants
* Importance of reconnaissance geophysical studies to better understand the geometrical structure of faults activated during earthquakes

Entities:

* Japan
* Tectonic plate convergence
* Subduction zones
* Intracontinental faults
* Nuclear power plants
* Chu-Etsu-Oki earthquake
* Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear power plant
* Reconnaissance geophysical studies

__data__.text:
Le Japon se situe à l’aplomb d’un point triple de convergence de plaques tectoniques(1)formant une zone de 
subduction(2)complexe (Figure 2). La plaque Philippine plonge sous la plaque Eurasie, la plaque Pacifique 
plonge sous les plaques Philippine et Eurasie au centre du  Japon, et sous la plaque nord-américaine au nord du 
Japon. Cette convergence se traduit d’une part par une forte sismicité localisée principalement au niveau des 
zones de subduction au large des côtes à des profondeurs importantes (typiquement de 30 à 150 km), d’autre 
part par l’existence de nombreuses failles actives intr acontinentales. Ces failles sont le siège d’une activité
sismique de moindre ampleur par rapport à la subduct ion, mais cette sismicité se produisant à faible 
profondeur (10-15 km) peut engendrer des dégâts importants. Le séisme de Chu-Etsu-Oki du 16 juillet 2007 est localisé en bordure côtière dans la zone de transition en tre le système de failles ac tives d’Itoigawa-Shizuoka et 
la zone de convergence de la mer du Japon. Ce séisme a permis d’accommoder une partie de la déformation 
résultant de la convergence, tout comme le séisme de Niigata Ken-Chu-Etsu de 2004 qui s’est produit à moins 
de 50 kilomètres de là. Des reconnaissances géophysiques sont planifiées d’ici la fin de l’année afin de mieux 
caractériser la géométrie de la faille ac tivée lors du séisme de Chu-Etsu-Oki (voir la note d'information de 
TEPCO du 17/08/2007 ), et notamment d’examiner la possibilité qu’une faille active émerge sur le site nucléaire 
de Kashiwazaki-Kariwa. 
Il s’agit pour le Japon du quatrième

The mission also noted numerous soil subsidence and landslides.

The Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant is the largest nuclear power plant in the world, producing approximately 8,200 megawatts of electricity. The earthquake caused significant damage to the plant, with three reactors experiencing an emergency shutdown and one reactor experiencing a planned shutdown. Another nuclear power plant, the Shika Nuclear Power Plant, also experienced damage due to a similar earthquake that occurred in March 2007. The section also discusses the accelerations of the soil that were recorded during the earthquake and the consequences of the earthquake on the nuclear power plants.

metadata.prev_section_summary: The section discusses the current seismic activity in the region of Mulhouse, France, following the September 2022 earthquake. The precise location of these seismic activities can contribute to identifying active structures in the region today. The section also discusses the historical sismic activity in the region of Bâle, Switzerland, and the implications for future earthquakes. The region of Bâle is marked by a recurrent sismicity, with several seismes d'intensité épicentrale supérieur à V, the most important being the séismes de Bâle de 1356 (intensités MSK=VII-VIII et IX-X). The failles associated with these historical events remain poorly known, and nothing can be confirmed at present that the structures responsible for these seismes are the same as those responsible for the 2022 earthquake (Figure 3).
metadata.section_summary:
The section discusses the consequences of the September 10, 2022 earthquake on nuclear power plants in France, specifically the Fessenheim site. The earthquake was located approximately 25 km from the Fessenheim site and was felt and recorded by the site's seismic monitoring system. The levels of seismic activity recorded led to EDF stopping certain operations and conducting material inspections.

The reference technical standard used in France to determine the levels of solicitation required to protect nuclear power plants is RFS 2001-01. This standard involves defining zones, called sismotectonic zones, where the potential seismic activity is considered homogeneous. Historical seismic activity is then studied, and it is assumed that similar seismic events could occur in any part of the sismotectonic zone. The macroseismic intensity of these seismic events is then increased by 1 to determine the solicitation. In the case of the Fessenheim site, the alea sismique (seismic risk) retained by EDF corresponds to a macroseismic intensity of VII-VIII (after majoration). The occurrence of the September 10, 2022 earthquake, with an intensity of IV, does not seem to be of a nature to challenge the alea sismique retained for the Fessenheim site.

The key topics discussed in the section include the consequences of the September 10, 2022 earthquake on the Fessenheim site, the reference technical standard used in France to determine the levels of solicitation required to protect nuclear power plants, and the alea sismique (seismic risk) retained by EDF for the Fessenheim site. The entities mentioned in the section include the Fessenheim site, the September 10, 2022 earthquake, the reference technical standard RFS 2001-01, and the alea sismique.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the earthquake that occurred in Amatrice, Italy on August 24, 2016. The earthquake had a magnitude of Mw 6.0, according to the Istituto Nazionale di Geofisica e Vulcanologia (INGV). The epicenter of the earthquake was located at a latitude of 42.70° North and a longitude of 13.24° East, between the epicenters of the earthquakes in L'Aquila in 2009 (Mw 6.3) and Ombrie-Marches in 1997 (Mw 5.7, 6.0, and 5.6). The earthquake was followed by numerous aftershocks, including a Mw 5.4 aftershock that occurred near the city of Norcia less than an hour after the main shock. The section also discusses the impact of the earthquake on the surrounding areas, including the loss of life, injuries, and displacement of people.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the impact of the Amatrice Earthquake on nuclear power plants and waste disposal sites in Italy. The earthquake did not directly affect any nuclear power plants or waste disposal sites located in the epicenter of the earthquake. However, several nuclear reactors and facilities for the production of nuclear fuel were affected. These installations, along with waste disposal sites and some research laboratories, are currently being dismantled. The Casaccia ENEA research facility, located about 100 km north of Rome, is the closest nuclear facility to the epicenter of the earthquake. The Montalto di Castro and Latina nuclear reactors are also located about 140 km from the epicenter. The section highlights the importance of understanding the seismic activity in the Apennines region of Italy, which is known to have a high seismic risk. The section also notes that the Amatrice Earthquake caused significant damage in the epicenter, but the human and material damage is not yet fully known.

The importance of the damage is likely due to the shallow depth of the earthquake and the vulnerability of the constructions. No nuclear sites were located in the area where significant effects were observed. Similar-sized earthquakes (magnitude 6.0) have occurred in France in the past (e.g. the Lambesc earthquake in 1909), and are possible to occur again. However, the frequency of such earthquakes is notably higher in Italy (once every 10 years on average) compared to France (once every 100 years on average).

The North-Anatolian Fault (NAF) has ruptured in several earthquakes along its length in the 20th century, including the Izmit earthquake in 1999 and the Erzincan earthquake in 1939.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses an earthquake that occurred in Fukushima, Japan on February 13, 2021. The earthquake had a magnitude of 7.1 (Mw - JMA) and was located 50 km deep and 70 km from the East coast of Honshu, Japan. The epicenter of the earthquake was located approximately 100 kilometers from the cities of Sendai and Iwaki and 70 kilometers from the Fukushima nuclear power plant. The earthquake occurred 10 years after the 2011 Tohoku earthquake, which had a magnitude of 9.0 and caused a major tsunami that led to the Fukushima nuclear disaster. The 2021 earthquake did not produce a tsunami, but it was the strongest earthquake to hit the region since the 2011 earthquake. metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the regional geodynamics and seismic activity in Japan, with a focus on the 13 February 2021 earthquake and its aftershocks. The earthquake occurred in the subduction zone of the Pacific Plate beneath the Eurasian Plate, with a surface slip of 45 km x 25 km. The seismic recordings indicate a compression rupture, but the scientific consensus is still unclear on the origin of the rupture, whether it occurred at the interface of the plates or within the subducting plate. The earthquake was located at a depth of about 50 km and is considered a continuation of the 2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami, even 10 years later. The section also mentions the occurrence of dozens of aftershocks, some of which were of magnitude greater than 5, and the authorities' recommendation to remain vigilant for future occurrences.

The earthquake caused injuries to over 100 people and significant damage to several buildings in Napa and Vallejo, including three historic buildings.

metadata.prev_section_summary: The section discusses the complex tectonic structure of the Japanese archipelago and its relationship to the high seismic activity in the region. It explains that the archipel is situated at the convergence of three tectonic plates: the Philippine, Eurasian, and Pacific plates. The rapid convergence of these plates generates a strong sismic activity, primarily located at the level of the zones of contact between the subducting plates. The section also provides information on the typical depths and locations of major earthquakes in the Japanese archipelago, which are generally situated at depths between 10 and 50 km and at large distances from the coast. The section includes figures and references to support the information provided.
metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the impact of the 2011 Tohoku Earthquake on Japan's Geospatial Information Authority (GSI) and compares it to other coastal regions before and after the earthquakes. The analysis of GPS data from the GSI's network of instruments helped in estimating the dimensions of the fault that ruptured during the earthquake and the distribution of slip on the fault. The section also highlights that Japan has the most comprehensive instrumentation for analyzing and studying earthquakes. The preliminary analysis of the geodetic and seismological data allows for the estimation of the dimension of the fault that ruptured, the evaluation of the slip distribution on the fault, and the determination of the magnitude of moment of the earthquake.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the impact of the 2011 Tohoku Earthquake and Tsunami on seismic acceleration measurements at nuclear power plants on the North-Eastern coast of Honshu in Japan. The four nuclear power plants that automatically shut down due to the first seismic shock during the earthquake are Onagawa, Fukushima Daiichi, Fukushima Daini, and Tokai. The maximum acceleration values (PGA) recorded by the KiK-net and K-net sismological networks at each of the nuclear power plants in Japan vary greatly, with some stations recording values as high as 3 g. The variations in PGA are likely due to the unique geological characteristics of each station.

The event was widely felt by the population within a radius of several hundred kilometers (up to the Dominican Republic, Cuba, and Jamaica). The section also mentions that the area where the earthquake occurred is a region with a high seismic risk (Calais, 2007).

Higher-level summary: The context provides information about New Zealand's earthquakes and faults, specifically the Alpine Fault and the GreenDale Fault. The Alpine Fault is a major transform fault that runs along the boundary between the Australian and Pacific Plates, while the GreenDale Fault is a secondary fault that is oblique to the Alpine Fault. The GreenDale Fault was previously unknown to geologists, but studies have shown that it has not ruptured in at least 16,000 years and is a decrochant fault that runs for approximately 80 kilometers. The context also discusses the relationship between the two faults and their impact on New Zealand's seismic activity.

metadata.section_summary:
The section discusses New Zealand's earthquakes and faults, specifically the Alpine Fault and the GreenDale Fault. The Alpine Fault is a major transform fault that runs along the boundary between the Australian and Pacific Plates, while the GreenDale Fault is a secondary fault that is oblique to the Alpine Fault. The GreenDale Fault was previously unknown to geologists, but studies have shown that it has not ruptured in at least 16,000 years and is a decrochant fault that runs for approximately 80 kilometers. The section also discusses the relationship between the two faults and their impact on New Zealand's seismic activity.

Key topics:

* New Zealand's earthquakes and faults
* Alpine Fault and GreenDale Fault
* Decrochant fault
* Seismic activity

metadata.prev_section_summary: The section discusses the geological history and seismic activity of the GreenDale fault in New Zealand. The fault is a 80 km long, horizontal fault located primarily to the west of Christchurch, but extending under the city. The fault has been active with over 4,000 seismic events recorded since September 2010, and the February 21, 2011 earthquake was a strong aftershock following a primary earthquake in September 2010. The fault is characterized by the presence of inverted faults at its ends, which affect its overall behavior. The section also mentions that there are no nuclear installations in New Zealand.
metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the types of deformation observed on the fault during two earthquakes: September 3, 2010 and February 21, 2011. The deformation is depicted in Figure 3, which shows "balloons" representing the type of deformation on the fault. The magnitude of the earthquakes is related to the size of the "balloons" depicted in Figure 3. The section also explains the difference between the mechanism of the September 3, 2010 earthquake and the February 21, 2011 earthquake, as shown in Figure 3. The mechanism of the September 3, 2010 earthquake is in pure decrochement, while the mechanism of the February 21, 2011 earthquake is in compression with a slight composante decrochante. The size of the "balloons" is proportional to the magnitude of the earthquakes.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the 2012 earthquake that occurred in Emilia-Romagna, Italy, which had a magnitude of 6.1 and occurred at a depth of approximately 6 km in the Pô plain, 36 km north of Bologne. The epicenter of the earthquake was located at 44.89° North, 11.23° East. The most affected communities were Finale Emilia, Ferrara, Rovigo, and Mantova. Two aftershocks of magnitude greater than 5 have been recorded so far (by INGV). The earthquake caused 7 deaths and 50 injuries, with some of the casualties being caused by the collapse of an industrial building. Many historical buildings were also severely damaged, including the Château Estense in Ferrara, whose tower partially collapsed. The earthquake was widely felt by the population within a radius of over 200 km. The aftershocks were felt over a large area of 40 km between Ferrara and Mantova, suggesting a complex rupture involving multiple faults. The region where the earthquake occurred is marked by both instrumental and historical sismic activity.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the impact of the Emilia-Romagna Earthquake in 2005 on the art, history, agriculture, and local communities in Italy. The initial casualties and injuries reported after the earthquake were 7 deaths and 50 injuries, with over 5,000 people evacuated in the region. The most affected areas were located between Modena and Ferrara, and the damage was particularly severe to the artistic and historical heritage. Several historical centers were closed to the public, including Mirandola, Massa Finalese, San Felice, Sant'Agostino, and Finale Emilia. The earthquake also had a significant impact on the agricultural industry in the region. The section includes a figure showing the initial values of seismic intensity for the affected area, which were obtained through post-sismic surveys.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses a moderate earthquake that occurred in Saint-Paul-sur-Ubaye, France on February 26, 2012. The earthquake had a magnitude of 4.3 to 4.8, depending on the source, and was estimated to be approximately 6 km deep. The earthquake was widely felt by the population in the south of France and in the Piedmont region of Italy. The intensities of the earthquake, as collected by the BCSF, reached V (a strongly felt earthquake with slight damage to vulnerable buildings). Several aftershocks of low magnitude have already been recorded, with the most significant occurring on February 27, 2012, with a magnitude of 4. The earthquake is associated with a mechanism called "en faille normale à composante décrochante" (a normal fault with a sliding component), which is characteristic of the region in the Alps. Saint-Paul-sur-Ubaye has experienced several earthquakes in the past, with the most severe occurring on April 5, 1959, with an intensity of VII-VIII and a magnitude of approximately 5.

The two earthquakes occurred 350 km to the west of the epicenter of the 2004 Sumatra-Andaman earthquake and tsunami, which had devastating effects on the region. metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the subduction of the Indo-Australian Plates under the Sunda Plate in Sumatra and its impact on seismic activity in the region. The subduction is significant due to the strong convergence rate of approximately 7 cm/year, which leads to high levels of seismic and volcanic activity. The section also highlights the 2004 Aceh earthquake and tsunami, which were major events in the region and had a devastating impact on the local population. Since 2004, there have been several significant earthquakes along the subduction zone, including the 2012 earthquakes, which differed from previous subduction earthquakes in terms of their location, magnitude, and associated deformation mechanisms.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the 2011 Van Earthquake in Turkey and its impact on nuclear power plants in Armenia. The section also mentions the estimated intensity of the earthquake in the epicenter, which was between VIII and IX on the Mercalli scale, and the presence of six strong aftershocks with magnitudes between 5 and 6. The section concludes with a reference to the Bureau d'évaluation des risques sismiques pour la sûreté des installations (BERSSIN) of the IRSN, which conducted research and expertises on the seismic risk as an external aggression factor for nuclear power plants.

The active fault in the region causing the earthquakes is the NW-SE decrochement of Ercis, which is relayed to the east by the Chaldiran fault.

The 2011 Virginia Earthquake, which affected the Central Virginia Seismic Zone, was a strong earthquake that produced a localized seismic activity. The 2008 earthquake had intensities ranging from II to III (light to moderate) within a 1,000 km radius of the epicenter, with maximum intensities of VII (very strong) in the epicentral zone. The 2011 earthquake had intensities ranging from II to III (light to moderate) within a 1,000 km radius of the epicenter, with maximum intensities of VII in the epicentral zone and a zone of intensity VI (strong) extending over 200 km in an oblong shape oriented SO-NE, possibly due to the orientation of the geological structures. The section also discusses the role of the USGS in analyzing the data and the factors that contributed to the large area of perception of the earthquakes, such as the low attenuation of the signal with distance in this region of the United States.
metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the impact of an earthquake on the North Anna Nuclear Power Plant in Virginia. The earthquake caused the two reactors to automatically shut down due to the loss of connection with the power grid. The plant's emergency generators took over the power supply to the safety systems. The plant was put on alert level 2, and the NRC's regional offices were also put on alert. The earthquake caused no significant damage to the plant, and the site is currently being inspected by NRC employees and inspectors. The NRC has reported that other nuclear power plants in the area also experienced the earthquake without any disruption to their operations. The report states that the North Anna Nuclear Power Plant is designed to withstand a maximum acceleration of 0.06 g (Operating Basis Earthquake) and 0.12 g (Design Basis Earthquake) during the design process. The accelerometer readings obtained on the site will be used to determine if the plant was damaged during the earthquake.

metadata.prev_section_summary:
The section discusses the different methods used to estimate the magnitude of an earthquake and their applications. The three methods are:

1. Magnitude local (Ml) estimated from the amplitude of the volume waves.
2. Magnitude of moment (Mw) estimated from the energy contained in the seismic signal.
3. Magnitude of surface waves (Ms) estimated from the amplitude of the surface waves.

The section also explains how seismic networks use local magnitudes (Ml) to monitor and analyze earthquakes, and the difference between Ml and other magnitude scales used in seismology. Additionally, the section discusses the difference between the magnitude of moment (Mw) and the magnitude of surface waves (Ms), and their uses in seismology. The section also mentions the use of the magnitude of moment (Mw) for evaluating the movement sismique for a nuclear power plant and the use of the magnitude of surface waves (Ms) for evaluating historical earthquakes.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the spectral response and seismic safety evaluations of nuclear power plants. The section mentions three nuclear power plants located within a 50 km radius of the earthquake epicenter, with the nearest being the centrale nucléaire de Cruas. The distance to the nearest fault zone is approximately 12 km. The attenuation of the seismic wave is significant due to the magnitude and shallow depth of the earthquake. At a distance of 2 km, the seismic stations recorded accelerations of a few milligrams per second (g), including 0.006 g at the centrale du Tricastin. At Cruas, the instruments installed on the site recorded a maximum acceleration of 0.045 g in free field, and another measurement taken inside the plant triggered a procedure for stopping and verifying the installations. The section also discusses the concept of a "spectre de réponse" used for the third safety examination of the centrale nucléaire de Cruas, which is a measure of the solicitation of a building or equipment to different vibration frequencies produced by an earthquake. The corresponding acceleration value used to determine the "spectre de réponse" is referred to as the "valeur de calage".

metadata.document_title: "Assessing the Need for Revision of SMHV and SMS at Tricastin and Cruas Nuclear Power Plants in Light of Recent Earthquake Data: Analysis of Spectral Response"
metadata.questions_this_excerpt_can_answer:

metadata.prev_section_summary: The section discusses the technical regulation (RFS 2001 -01) that defines the spectral response of nuclear power plants and how it is used to determine the seismic safety evaluations. The regulation requires defining zones (dite zones sismote ctoniques) that are considered homogeneous in terms of their potential to generate earthquakes, and then listing the most significant earthquakes known historically in each of these zones (sismicité instrumentale et sismicité historique). The sollicitat ion sismique retenue (Séisme Maximum Historiquement Vraisemblable - SMHV) is defined by assuming that the earthquakes identified can occur at any point in the zone sismotectonique to which they belong. The regulation requires that, in the zone sismotectonique of the site, the SMHV is assumed to occur at the surface of the site. The Séisme Majoré de Sécurité (SMS) is obtained by increasing the magnitude of the surface earthquakes (Ms) of the SMHV by 0.5. The section also mentions the importance of considering older seismic events (paléoséismes) in the seismic safety evaluation. The section provides an example of how the seismic safety evaluation for the nuclear power plants of Cruas and Tricastin is based on the 1873 earthquake in France, which defined a SMHV of magnitude Ms 4.7 to 4 km, and a SMS of magnitude Ms 5.2 to 4 km of depth. The section also mentions the importance of considering older seismic events (paléoséismes) in the seismic safety evaluation.
metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the recent earthquake that occurred on November 11, 2019, near the Tricastin and Cruas nuclear power plants. The earthquake had a magnitude of approximately 4.5 (estimated from a Mw 5 magnitude) and a depth of approximately 2 km. The spectral response of the earthquake is compared to the SMHV and SMS values currently in place at the Tricastin and Cruas nuclear power plants. The spectral response of the earthquake is found to be similar to the SMHV, and therefore, the IRSN recommends revising the SMHV and SMS values at the Tricastin and Cruas nuclear power plants based on the recent earthquake data. The section also mentions the IRSN's previous recommendation in 2016 to EDF to demonstrate that the SMS considered is not affected by new data related to the historical earthquakes of 1186 and 1448 in the region of Uzès.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the 2002 Nahrin Earthquake in Afghanistan, which occurred on March 25, 2002, in the Hindu Kush mountain range, approximately 160 km north of Kabul. The earthquake caused significant damage to the city of Nahrin, with over 1800 deaths, 4000 injuries, and 20,000 people left homeless. The magnitude of the earthquake was estimated to be between 5.8 and 6.1 by various organizations, and it was followed by several aftershocks, including one with a magnitude of 5. The earthquake's unique characteristics included superficial fissures with depths of up to 10 kilometers, which is different from the typical earthquakes in the region with fissures reaching depths of 330 kilometers. The earthquake was caused by a surface rupture of a north-south fault, which is believed to be a local compression source. Despite efforts, sismologists have not been able to associate the earthquake with a cartographied fault.

Additionally, there have been more than a dozen earthquakes of magnitude greater than 7 since 1900 in the Hindu Kush, primarily located in the province of Samangan. The cause of the high seismic activity in the Hindu Kush region is the collision-subduction of the Indian and Eurasian tectonic plates, which causes certain faults to reach very deep levels. The sismicité récente en Inde, between 1904 and 1995, is also discussed in relation to the earthquake that occurred in Gurajat, India on January 26, 2001.
metadata.section_summary: The section discusses the 2000 Himalayan Earthquake in the Indian Subcontinent, which was caused by a vertical movement of a fault (mechanism in chevauchement). The earthquake was a superficial one, with the majority of the movement occurring on a depth of 17 km, over a length of approximately 150 km. The state of Gurajat in India is the second most industrialized state in the country, with industries such as cotton, silk, and chemical industries being the most important. The earthquake in Gurajat was a surprise because it occurred outside of the usual seismic activity in the region, which is typically located in the north of India, near the Himalayas, where the Indian and Eurasian Plates meet (as shown in Figure 2). The movement of the Indian Plate in relation to the Eurasian Plate contributes to the seismic activity in the Indian Subcontinent, and this has implications for the region's geology and geography. The Indian Plate is composed of ancient rocks, some of which are among the oldest in the craton, and the sismicity of this craton is relatively low.

metadata.section_summary: The section discusses a 7.0 magnitude earthquake that occurred in Myiagi, Japan on May 26, 2003. The epicenter was located off the coast of the island of Honshu, in the prefecture of Miyagi, and approximately 390 km north-northeast of Tokyo. The hypocenter was located at a depth of approximately 70 km. The section also mentions that several aftershocks were recorded in the hours following the earthquake. Over 100 people were injured, and the earthquake was felt as far away as Tokyo, where it lasted for 1 to 2 minutes. The section also notes that Japan has a dense network of accelerometer measurements on its surface, with some stations being doubled in depth to study the effects of subsurface layers on seismic waves. The acceleration recorded on the surface of the earth was very high, exceeding 0.5 g in a large area.
